TextBlock.TextLine: tl
Antw: 13 feb 1682
Mons Michel vallgo
iporten
mMons sedert dat ick op 5 en 7 deser differente paxkens aen ul
hebbe gesonden, en hebbe om ul deswegens niet vernomen,
eghter hope de selve ul wel sijn geworden. heden vertreckt
pr. bode verscrieck een paxken EA:81N.15 waer vore post geliejt
te betalen al ordinare, en de dopescheren naer londen aen
Mons Edmundwarner stellende de oncosten op sijn rekening
godt sent alles salvo & naer groet blijve n D75
Jonnes Melijn
Meebllen
mons van aken Antw: 13 br 1682
mons verhope dat ul. wel thuys sal fijn gekomen
ende dat de goedern heden oock wel sullen
ariveren, alloo de selve noch gisteren avont sijn
vertrocken in gesloten is de facture vant geneeve
van mij helft gehoest: de perpeumen worden in
de verf gegeven, ende soo haest als de selvve gedaen
sijn aln ul gesonden, hebbe de drij honderten
wijsligh guldens van Jff Spusl begijntien ontfangen
de sondert envijstigh aeest mons kersavont geseijdt
heden oft morgen te betalen deen on dan derwort
ul in credit gestelt, en waer in ick ul kan
voorder in dinst doen gelieft mij liberlijck te
comanderen sal altijt tracten ve wel te dienee
London mr. Actur annetlay
thourgh I am to blame for not haveingh performed my word yett if you kneow what hath
beer the hinderance, you would castly excuse mee & depending npon yd. deserasion, do not
in large upon that point, so referre my self to the inclosed acctt, sy yd. cur. is due to
you £859„6„5 ½ for which I'll endeavour all I can to procure the valew & remitt you
I hope next month to remitt the most past, for then is mony coming in dayly, whire
as now there is non stutring yett, which I do not a little aribute the innfortunate samdas
happened here aboutt, yett onting doth comfort mee, that as long children come natet so
woreld, our trade must yo, & he that hath no mony, shall have no creditt
Pray examn all, & finding rught note in conformitie I hope you will finde itt so
content in the income while I do vere much want ene bale of serges more for which
returne you the patt. of N. 24. that you please to send them tom. wood to provide
the same assortment in one bale in prijses as the lost wore, butt he must provide
them better penniworths, though the collours were indifferent except the sparree grayes
of which some were to dullish, so recommend that crusteley, & in case you finde thingh
to content I'Il norder some what more, butt fiest yd aprobation, whilst never thie
less neglat not one mimutt I this bale to be shipt oft att exan
Londen m. Henriy Maynand
my last to you was on the 7 cur so which please to be referred, blcause sonce non from you
yett hope, you well alllaved them, & that you bee well arrived, as also in a good forwardnots in the
providing of the desired goods, haveing the most haste whith sach whites & the 6 N silver manckhs
stuck cloathes, besides the bayes from the north. inclosed is a pattarn accord to which please
to sprovide 2y of blews, though they might be some what more lively in callour yett, as light
& in payse not opeeed 5 s a yd or 5:2 a 3 pence att furthest, Io them please to add 4
anockk N13.1 of about 5 ƒ a yd, 4 of about 5:6 & t of 6ƒ and one of about 7 se yd, to be
belrathes in a bale to be espotched as soone as por., inclosed my bill for £120 st on m.
abram Vivian in fauour of m. Paris slaughter, which please to deliver him, & he my procure
that valew, that you bee not seen concerned do said vivian. as soone as I know how m.
slaughter hath composed, or sett led the concernes with Peeters shall endeavour to remitt mone
he may answer him self to mee att the receipt of the inclosed, I would be faire ind
of that bustijness, according to my promise shall now endeavour to remitt what pou. I car bo
you il
C 14d
Londen m. Abram Vivian
acorins to a letter from yo. brother Jacob vivian exspest the goods I me ame bayes from
the north vere first vessel for I do much want them, as also to know if you intend to be here
and att what time to governe my self accordingly because I shall want a good assortment
of clrathes, & I must take my measures when to In order them to have the advantidge
of the markett & nott te be backward, when sale comis: yor acctt. curtt. followes I next pose
without anj more delay, this day have drawne on you £120- in my bill payable to m
Banis slaughter att 2115 att 35.2 for the vallew of m. ant. Peeters & Comp, for which please
te give all due honour, as also the £72- drawne on m. George cole, where with I'll constrive
to desist, if pow itt is to be don, in hopes to receave mony for my further rembourse
out of our standing out debts, butt I assure you I have been vere much pinched to pay
yd blls, I exspect yd advise of all att lage
An mr. Will. Cobb & Comp
In answer to yd of 13 past, as yett for want of sale have not opened yo bole sent mee
butt depending upon the caraeter you give the goods, do here inclosed send you patt for 30 soper
for a purther tayall to procud accordingly, for wee sell too serges 22 yd. that wee do not
sell to cloth serges, where fore do as yu love yd owne Inrest, for if you do well I'll proceed
butt if not l'l desirt, I would these serges have to be the vere best goods that are to
behadd, though meeshinckss 42 a 43 ƒt is a great pryse they must be sent to Bruges t my
order & the patt. & bill of loading dineetely to mee I post
The bale to cont12 modec: gold & blaey 22 yd.
8 sparaw graijs . 12 yt. 3 of 39„40 a 43 ƒ4 yd
5 pajes stone & steel grays of 37 a 38 ƒ a
5 muss paijs . of 40 a 41 p 6ƒ
30 S though I limit in some manner the prijses yett referre itt
wholly to you to do well & to send mee pure good goods, not hott calandred, butt whith gold
press, smoodley frest, I exspect yd answor I first, because I would have the goods comets
fust vessel. I have acepts mr. sole his bre for the formar bale, & he will do the like
for ths, or I'll remitt dixcetely
